Graphical abstract This review highlights advancements in bifunctional oxygen electrocatalyst design and construction and discusses strategies, self-supported air cathodes on carbon and metal substrates, their applications in flexible zinc-air batteries, and future challenges and opportunities. Smart wearable devices are regarded to be the next prevailing technology product after smartphones and smart homes, and thus there has recently been rapid development in flexible electronic energy storage devices. Among them, flexible solid-state zinc-air batteries have received widespread attention because of their high energy density, good safety, and stability. Efficient bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts are the primary consideration in the development of flexible solid-state zinc-air batteries, and self-supported air cathodes are strong candidates because of their advantages including simplified fabrication process, reduced interfacial resistance, accelerated electron transfer, and good flexibility. This review outlines the research progress in the design and construction of nanoarray bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts. Starting from the configuration and basic principles of zinc-air batteries and the strategies for the design of bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts, a detailed discussion of self-supported air cathodes on carbon and metal substrates and their uses in flexible zinc-air batteries will follow. Finally, the challenges and opportunities in the development of flexible zinc-air batteries will be discussed. Keywords Bifunctional electrocatalysts Oxygen reduction reaction Oxygen evolution reaction Self-supported air electrodes Flexible zinc-air batteries 1 Introduction With the advent of the mobile internet era, smart wearable devices have attracted enormous attention. At the same time, with the continuous iteration of big data, cloud computing, and Internet of Things (IoT) technologies, there is much greater room for the development of these smart wearable devices, especially in the fields of intelligent medical care, telemedicine, and mobile medical care [1]. Smart wearable devices are becoming an emerging technology that can change human health and lifestyle. In this regard, traditional energy storage devices can no longer meet consumers’ demand for smart wearable devices with diverse functions and hence simpler, and more portable and flexible energy storage devices need to be developed [2]. Compared with traditional electronics, flexible electronics exhibit greater stretchability and ductility, and thus can adapt to different working environments and withstand different types of distortions such as twisting, bending, stretching, and folding. In the meantime, battery life has become a key concern for researchers as well consumers. The most advanced rechargeable lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) are hindered by their limited energy density (200–250 W h kg−1), inadequate safety, and comparatively high price of electrode materials (e.g., Li and Co) [3,4]. In this context, metal-air batteries have attracted ample attention because of their high energy density. Their semi-open configuration using oxygen from ambient air allows them to reduce the mass and volume of the cell, resulting in a relatively higher energy density [5,6]. Among the various types of metal-air batteries, zinc-air batteries (ZABs) are unique because of their special advantages. Firstly, ZABs offer a high degree of safety, as the chemical activity of zinc metal in an aqueous or solid-state electrolyte ensures continuous electrochemical reactions without violent reactions in air [7]. When it is used in flexible and wearable devices, serious safety problems caused by exposing to air or short circuits due to continuous deformation can be avoided.Secondly, ZABs have a large energy density (1086 W h kg−1), which ensures that flexible devices can be powered up for long periods of time without being charged [8,9]. Finally, the abundance in the earth crust and low cost of zinc make it a promising candidate for flexible and wearable energy storage devices [10–12]. Despite the advantages of ZABs, the actual cycle life and energy conversion efficiency are still unsatisfactory [13]. This mainly stems from the slow electrochemical reactions on the cathode, namely oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) during discharge and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) during charge [14]. The complex reaction mechanisms of both reactions, involving multiple electron transfer processes, lead to slow kinetics and high overpotential [15,16]. Therefore, the exploration of efficient bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts to catalyze the ORR and OER processes is crucial for the further development of rechargeable ZABs. Given the portable and flexible characteristics of wearable electronic devices, materials for air cathodes also need to be adequately flexible. Although over a hundred types of powder catalysts are now available, they often require the use of other conductive substrates to attain flexibility [17–20]. This will inevitably lead to problems such as additive usage and catalyst shedding and thus the development of self-supported air cathodes is crucial for the practical application of rechargeable ZABs [21–23]. In recent years, significant progress has been made in the development of flexible ZAB devices, driven by the growing demand for lightweight and adaptable energy storage solutions. While previous review literature has explored various aspects of ZABs, it is essential to highlight the evolving landscape of flexible ZAB technology [24,25]. In this review, we will not only concentrate on the development of self-supported bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts for flexible ZABs but also address the shifting paradigms in flexible ZAB research. To set the stage, we will briefly describe the construction and working principle of rechargeable ZABs, followed by an introduction to innovative strategies for the design of bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts. Subsequently, we will provide an overview of recently-reported self-supported oxygen electrocatalysts on metal or carbon substrates and their applications in flexible ZABs. Finally, we will explore both the challenges and the promising opportunities in the dynamic field of flexible ZABs, highlighting the advancements that distinguish the current state of research. 2 Fundamentals of rechargeable Zn-air batteries 2.1 Battery configuration and working principles Rechargeable Zn-air batteries are a new type of energy transfer and storage devices. As shown in Fig. 1 (a), a standard ZAB consists of a zinc anode, an electrolyte, a separator, and an air cathode [13,26]. Most of the current studies on ZABs have been conducted in alkaline electrolytes. So far, the flexible ZABs that have been reported are based on two main design forms: sandwich/flat type and cable type, as shown in Fig. 1(b and c) [27–30]. To separate the cathode from the anode and to achieve ion conduction, alkaline solid electrolytes were developed to replace liquid electrolytes. This can meet the requirements for portability and wear resistance of flexible devices while solving the problems of solvent volatilization and leakage to a certain extent. Loading high-efficiency electrocatalyst at the three-phase electrolyte-catalyst-air interface is beneficial to the enhancement of the output voltage stability and cycling stability of the battery. The charge-discharge functions of the rechargeable ZABs are realized by cathodic oxygen reduction and anodic zinc metal oxidation. The reaction process can be briefly summarized as follows. During the discharging process, the O2 in air diffuses through the air cathode and then carry out ORR in the presence of the catalyst loaded on the electrode. On the other hand, the oxidation process of zinc occurs at the negative zinc electrode. In the process, the generated OH− rely on the electrolyte for conduction, while the released electrons form a discharge current in the external circuit. The equations are as follows. A i r e l e c t r o d e : O 2 + 4 e - + 2 H 2 O → 4 O H - Z i n c e l e c t r o d e : Z n + 4 O H - → Z n ( O H ) 4 2 - + 2 e - Z n ( O H ) 4 2 - → Z n O + H 2 O + 2 O H - T o t a l r e a c t i o n : 2 Z n + O 2 → 2 Z n O The OER process happens to be the reverse reaction of the ORR process, generating oxygen and depositing zinc on the surface of the metal electrode at the same time. 2.2 Air cathodes 2.2.1 Structure of air cathodes The air electrode primarily consists of a current collector (e.g., nickel foam and stainless steel), a gas diffusion layer (providing pathways for oxygen), and a catalyst layer. It is worth noting that the gas diffusion layer is of hydrophobicity and possesses a large surface area, facilitating the contact and diffusion of atmospheric oxygen while preventing electrolyte leakage [32]. A mixture of porous carbon materials and polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) is commonly used as the gas diffusion layer [33]. The ORR/OER reactions occur in the active layer, which is coated on the current collector surface and in contact with the electrolyte, while the gas diffusion layer is placed on the opposite side of the current collector, in contact with the atmosphere, forming a sandwich-like structure. To enhance the catalytic activity, catalyst layer utilization, and lifespan, carrier materials with high surface area and abundant active side chains are typically used [34]. Additionally, excellent conductivity, stability, and resistance to oxidation are crucial properties required for carrier materials in demanding electrochemical processes over extended periods [35]. Porous nanocarbon, owing to its unique physical and chemical properties, resource abundance, and low cost, has been widely applied as a carrier material [36,37]. As oxygen exhibits low solubility and diffusion coefficient in the electrolyte, it mainly exists in a gaseous form during the ORR process. Thus, the high surface area formed at the oxygen-KOH electrolyte-catalyst three-phase interface is vital for the air electrode [38]. To meet the strict requirements of the three-phase ORR reaction, effective contact between oxygen and the electrolyte on the catalyst surface, as well as the wettability of air electrode and electrolyte components (hydrophobicity/hydrophilicity), should be considered. Usually, the side in contact with the electrolyte (active catalyst layer) is hydrophilic, while the side in contact with the air (gas diffusion layer) should be hydrophobic. Moreover, ZAB is sensitive to ambient humidity, and good wettability can alleviate electrolyte evaporation losses and wetting. 2.2.2 Electrolyte Aqueous electrolyte: Although neutral and acidic electrolytes can slow down the formation of zinc dendrites and prevent carbonation, alkaline electrolytes are favorable for oxygen reaction kinetics and the stable presence of zinc, offering broader prospects for the application of this material. For ZAB, potassium hydroxide (KOH) and sodium hydroxide (NaOH) solutions are the most commonly used alkaline electrolytes. KOH is highly favored due to its higher ion conductivity, larger oxygen diffusion coefficient, lower viscosity, and higher solubility of zinc salts. To achieve excellent ion conductivity and kinetic behavior, electrolytes with KOH concentrations of 20% to 40% are typically used. Among them, a 30 wt% KOH solution exhibits the highest ionic conductivity up to 640 mS cm−1, resulting in faster reaction kinetics for zinc. Although the high solubility of zinc discharge products in KOH solution inhibits zinc surface passivation and thus increases zinc capacity, it also leads to the growth of zinc dendrites due to the formation of oversaturated Zn(OH)4 2− species in the electrolyte [3]. Currently, the effective approach to address these issues is the optimization of electrolyte composition (such as the use of additives), which can significantly reduce the polarization of the negative electrode during charge and discharge cycles and improve Coulombic efficiency. In addition, the reaction between KOH electrolyte and CO2 in the air generates carbonates [39]. These carbonates precipitate within the pores of the air electrode and on the surface of catalyst, not only obstructing the diffusion pathway of oxygen but also reducing the activity of catalyst, exacerbating the charge-discharge polarization of ZAB [40]. Although CO2 can be removed through physicochemical adsorption, the operational cost is high, which hinders practical development [41]. Apart from the impact of CO2 on ZAB performance, the volatility of the electrolyte itself and the humidity of the air also influence the stability of the electrolyte, subsequently affecting its viscosity and ion conductivity, leading to a gradual decline in battery performance over time. Solid-state electrolyte: Solid-state electrolytes have garnered significant attention due to their combination of solid mechanical properties and ionic conductivity similar to liquids [31,42,43]. Currently, improving the interface contact between the solid-state electrolyte and the air electrode remains challenging for solid-state ZAB [44]. As shown in Fig. 2 (a), in an aqueous electrolyte, catalysts with a high surface area on the air electrode can have full contact with the electrolyte, facilitating the electrochemical reaction of oxygen at three-phase reaction sites. In contrast, the wettability of solid-state electrolytes is poorer, significantly restricting the three-phase interface reaction [3,45]. Consequently, the interfacial resistance for OH− transport on the catalyst surface is much greater than that in aqueous electrolytes. During battery operation, significant interfacial resistance can result in low current density and high overpotential. Alkaline gel electrolytes (AGEs) formed by low-molecular-weight polymers in alkaline solutions have been developed and applied in ZAB. In these AGEs, low-molecular-weight polymers such as ethylene-based polymers and cellulose derivatives serve as mechanical matrices, and a large amount of alkaline solution causes their expansion to ensure high ionic conductivity [44,46,47]. AGEs based on polyacrylic acid, for instance, demonstrate similar levels of ionic conductivity to aqueous electrolytes (0.3 S cm−1). Assembled ZAB with such electrolytes can improve zinc utilization (82%–90%), approaching the theoretical capacity [48]. It should be noted that there needs a trade-off between ionic conductivity and mechanical strength since weak mechanical strength of AGEs may lead to unstable electrolyte-electrode contacts and, thus, higher interface resistance. Therefore, simultaneously enhancing ionic conductivity and mechanical properties is the key to achieving high performance in ZAB [49]. For example, Chen et al. [50] prepared a quaternized cellulose electrolyte membrane and applied it in ZAB, as shown in Fig. 2(b). The interconnected microporous structure of cellulose nanofibers achieved a high degree of hydration and high ionic conductivity while maintaining mechanical stability under hydrated conditions. Ionic liquids: Non-protonic ionic liquids (ILs) offer advantages such as non-volatility, non-flammability, and stable physicochemical properties, making them potential candidates for water-soluble electrolytes in the future [51,52]. The extremely low volatility of ionic liquids ensures an abundant supply of the electrolyte. Even more attractive is their ability to guarantee reversible deposition and dissolution of zinc, reducing dendrite formation, making them suitable for secondary ZAB. Studies have found that suitable ionic liquids, when used as electrolytes, can improve catalyst performance through different electrode-electrolyte interfaces, weakening the adsorption of non-active oxygen species on the electrocatalyst surface, thus ensuring fast mass transport of reactants [53,54]. For reaction processes requiring protons, such as the ORR reaction, protons can be extracted from the cations of ionic liquids; therefore, in practical operation, proton additives are typically introduced. The presence or absence of proton activity in ionic liquids, with or without additives, significantly influences the catalytic potential of the catalyst for ORR [55,56]. Currently, non-protonic electrolytes are in their early stages of development. Compared to KOH, their higher ionic resistance and different catalytic mechanisms result in lower catalytic activity. As a result, there is still much work to be done to further enhance the performance of ZAB using non-protonic electrolytes. 2.3 Oxygen reaction mechanism The ORR and OER involved in the air electrode during discharge/charge processes directly determine the performance of rechargeable ZABs. However, the kinetics of these two reactions is slow and the reaction mechanisms are intricate. To determine the mechanisms of the ORR and OER on an electrode, a combination of experimental techniques like Tafel analysis, rotating disk electrode measurements, and isotope labeling, alongside in situ characterization and theoretical modeling is usually employed. Comprehensive data analysis is essential for validating the findings and understanding of these reactions. The potential mechanisms of oxygen reactions in the alkaline electrolytes will be briefly described here. 2.3.1 ORR mechanism In the discharge process of ZABs, oxygen from the air continuously enters the cathode, and ORR takes place. In alkaline electrolytes, the ORR mechanism is usually divided into two pathways depending on the adsorption mode of O2 on the catalyst surface. The first mode is the adsorption of bidentate O2 onto the active site (*), followed by the generation of OH− via a four-electron pathway with the following reaction equations. ∗ + O 2 g + H 2 O l + e - → O O H ∗ + O H - a q O O H ∗ + e - → O ∗ + O H - a q O ∗ + H 2 O l + e - → O H ∗ + O H - a q O H ∗ + e - → ∗ + O H - a q The second one is a two-electron pathway in which the terminal adsorbed O2 is initially reduced to H2O2, and then further reduced to OH− according to the following reaction equations. O 2 + H 2 O l + 2 e - → H O 2 - + O H - a q H O 2 - + H 2 O l + 2 e - → 3 O H - a q This pathway is often applied to the production of H2O2 by electro-reduction, which is safer and faster than the traditional synthesis methods [57]. The ORR process involves multi-step electron transfer procedures and complex oxygen-containing intermediates, and the adsorption energy of oxygenated substances at the active site plays a crucial role in each step. By conducting calculations on various dense packed metal surfaces, Nørskov et al. [58] investigated the free energy of various intermediates and constructed a volcano plot linking the theoretical activity of ORR to ΔE O, with Pt located near the top of the volcano plot (Fig. 3 a). The Sabatier principle states that only the appropriate adsorption energy is favorable for the reaction. Proton-electron transfer to O* or OH* restricts the activity of metals that are bound too strongly to oxygen. Depending on the applied potential, the activity of metals that are coupled to oxygen too weakly is constrained by proton-electron transfer to O2* (an associative mechanism) or splitting of the O-O bond in O2 (a dissociative mechanism) [57]. For the cases where Pt is not situated at the top of the volcano plot, it has been demonstrated that metals with lower oxygen binding energies than Pt show comparatively faster ORR rates. Therefore, alloying Pt with 3d transition metals can further enhance the ORR activity [59,60]. The density functional theory (DFT) calculations have been carried out to find a connection for free energies of oxygen intermediates: Δ G O O H = Δ G O H + 3.2 ± 0.2 e V , Δ G O = 2 Δ G O H , and the scaling relationship diagrams are shown in Fig. 3(b) [61]. Even metals that are located near the top of the volcano plot and with the best oxygen binding energy will still have a certain non-zero theoretical overpotential as a result of this hard-to-break association, which will significantly restrict the catalytic activity. According to several studies, the conversion of O2 to OOH* determines the rate of ORR, and the change of the free energy of OOH* will also affect those free energies of other intermediates [62]. Therefore, the key to designing the catalyst is to appropriately optimize the adsorption energy of each radical reaction intermediate on the catalyst surface. 2.3.2 OER mechanism During the charge of ZABs, OER proceeds in a manner reverse to the 4e− ORR pathway [63,64]. The reaction mechanism of OER is usually considered to involve two possible pathways: the adsorbate evolution mechanism (AEM) and the lattice oxygen mediated mechanism (LOM), where AEM is considered to be the traditional and widely accepted mechanism [65]. AEM involves four synergistic proton-electron transfer processes focused on the active metal sites [66]. The adsorbed H2O initially forms OH* by a single-electron oxidation reaction on the metal site surface before being converted to O2. The subsequent proton-coupled electron transfer reaction oxidizes OH* to O*, and then the resulting O* intermediate reacts with another H2O to obtain OOH*. Ultimately, OOH* is oxidized to O2 through a single-electron oxidation process. The detailed equations are shown below. ∗ + O H - a q → O H ∗ + e - Δ G 1 O H ∗ + O H - a q → O ∗ + H 2 O l + e - Δ G 2 O ∗ + O H - a q → O O H ∗ + e - Δ G 3 O O H ∗ + O H - a q → O 2 g + H 2 O l + ∗ + e - Δ G 4 The binding strength of the intermediates on the surface of catalysts, like ORR, is the primary determinant of overpotential in OER, which follows the Sabatier principle [67]. The OER activity and intermediate adsorption energy are tightly connected to each other in the AEM mechanism. The adsorption energy of intermediates is linearly correlated, which helps to screen catalysts quickly, but the barriers of OER activity continue to be intractable [66]. The rate-determining step is the one with the largest free energy, i.e., G = m a x [ Δ G 1 , Δ G 2 , Δ G 3 , Δ G 4 ] , and the theoretical overpotential of OER is η = G e - 1.23 V [66,68]. Based on the results of DFT calculations and considering that the adsorption of OH− and O2 release steps rarely play a key role in determining the potential in most OER catalysis, Δ G O ∗ - Δ G O H ∗ is commonly used as an indication of the OER catalytic activity of metal-based catalysts [69]. By plotting the relationship between η and Δ G O ∗ - Δ G O H ∗ as a function of the volcano plot in Fig. 3(c and d), it is found that the best active OER catalysts have moderately strong oxygen binding and the Δ G O ∗ - Δ G O H ∗ value is located at the top of the volcano plot [66]. The potential-determining step on the left and right branches varied because of the strength of binding to oxygen, respectively, influenced by the formation of HOO* species and the deprotonation of HO* species [66,70]. Considering that the binding strength of oxygen-containing intermediates is greatly influenced by the electronic structure of the catalyst surface, the value of Δ G O ∗ - Δ G O H ∗ may be adjusted by modifying the electronic structure to produce a more superior catalyst [71–74]. 2.3.3 Ideal ORR/OER catalysts The ideal bifunctional oxygen electrocatalyst requires catalytic activities for both ORR and OER. The best noble metal catalyst for ORR and OER are Pt/C and IrO2, respectively, but they are expensive and not stable enough for long-term operation. The relationship between oxygen binding energy and theoretical activity in ORR and OER has been described earlier, and effective bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts require a proper oxygen binding energy. Rossmeisl et al. [75] described the free energy scaling relationship of oxygen intermediates for ORR adsorbates on metal-N-C catalysts as a function of ΔG OH*. They then established a bifunctional volcano plot between the ORR/OER activity and the free energy based on the scaling relationship, containing the free energy versus ΔG OH* for each step of the mechanism, as shown in Fig. 4 (a and b). The energy of the adsorption intermediates varies with the type of metal atom in metal-N-C, but the catalyst cannot reaches the optimal ORR/OER activity simultaneously. The ΔG OH* required to reach the top of the volcano varies, depending on the ratio of the intermediates which is the key consideration in the design of bifunctional electrocatalysts [76]. The scaling relationship needs to be altered so as to bring the vertices of the two volcano plots closer together to work out this issue. Excellent bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts are manufactured by modifying the structure, composition, and surface electronic state to achieve the proper oxygen binding energy [77–80]. 2.4 Evaluation method and parameters for Zn-air batteries The performance testing of rechargeable ZABs is not much different from the methods used for other common batteries. Typical evaluation indexes include open-circuit voltage (OCP), galvanodynamic polarization test, galvanostatic cycling test, galvanostatic full-discharge test, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy test, etc. This section provides a summary about the different electrochemical tests that are used to measure ZAB performance. 2.4.1 Galvanodynamic polarization test Measuring the galvanodynamic polarization potential response at different charge/discharge current densities can be the first step to evaluate the performance of rechargeable ZABs (current density-voltage curves). This curve (Fig. 5 a), which displays the charge/discharge features of the battery, is separated into three regions: the initial potential change, the intermediate quasi-linear change, and the intense deviation at high current densities. The amplitude of these potential variations reveals the activity of the air electrode where the initial steep potential drop during discharging and the voltage leap during charging are ascribed to the potentials necessary to break through the energy barriers of the ORR/OER. The internal polarization resistance of the battery, which includes the ion transport resistance in the electrolyte and the interfacial resistance at the electrolyte-electrode interface, is associated with the linear slope of the current density-voltage curve. In addition, a smaller slope indicates that the battery is operating more efficiently. The sharp voltage deviations at high current densities are due to insufficient ion support [3]. The power density curve is derived by multiplying the discharge potential with the applied current density to determine the peak power density. The energy conversion efficiency can be calculated from the ratio of the discharge voltage to the charge voltage, which serves as an index for battery energy utilization. 2.4.2 Galvanostatic full-discharge test By using a constant discharge current until a predetermined cutoff voltage is achieved, the galvanostatic full-discharge test measures a battery capacity (Fig. 5b). As the capacity of a ZAB is determined by the Zn electrode, the specific capacity of the battery can be measured using the consumption of the Zn electrode and compared to its theoretical specific capacity (820 mA h g−1 Zn). The specific capacity can be multiplied with the average discharge voltage to obtain the specific energy density normalized to the mass of Zn consumed (W h kg−1). The ideal discharge curve should be close to a flat and straight line. However, ohmic resistance, Zn electrode thickness, and wettability can all affect the actual discharge curve [81]. Usually, the capacity decreases as the discharge current density increases. This may be due to the faster formation of Zn(OH)4 2−, which results in an increased Zn(OH)4 2− concentration gradient and quicker formation of ZnO passivation layer on the electrode surface [3]. 2.4.3 Galvanostatic cycling test The galvanostatic cycling test can be used to measure the durability of the ZABs (Fig. 5c). By alternately applying a fixed positive charge current and a negative discharge current while recording the corresponding charge/discharge voltages, it is possible to observe the potential change of the ZAB during the charge/discharge cycles. A large number of short cycles are often used, in which the zinc electrode discharges to only a fraction of its capacity in each cycle, which is more favorable for determining the durability and response of the air electrode. Alternatively, a small number of cycles of longer duration, each of which is long enough to fully utilize the capacity of the Zn electrode, can be used to assess the actual charge retention rate of the ZABs [84]. In addition, calculating the ratio between the charge and discharge potentials also makes it possible to determine the round-trip efficiency of ZAB for each charge-discharge cycle. The ideal round-trip efficiency will stay still while the actual test will show a gradually decline in the round-trip efficiency as the number of cycles rises. Besides, the galvanostatic cycling test is a vital tool for assessing the durability of fabricated ZAB devices, and it is intricately linked to their practical applications. Ensuring that ZABs can endure numerous charge and discharge cycles is not only a technical challenge but also a key determinant of their real-world utility, economic viability, and environmental sustainability. Therefore, thorough evaluation of durability through such tests is essential to advance the field of energy storage and promote the adoption of ZABs in various industries. 2.4.4 Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy test Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) can reveal the resistance and capacitance of the components in a rechargeable ZAB (Fig. 5d). Usually, the EIS is performed during charge and discharge at a constant overpotential and the corresponding Nyquist diagram can be obtained. The series resistance (R s), charge transfer resistance (R ct), and electrode-electrolyte interface resistance (R i) can be deduced from the real and negative imaginary impedances at different frequencies. In general, a smaller charge transfer resistance implies a better ORR catalytic activity, leading to a higher discharge voltage and the same trend of OER activity during charging [15]. The electrode-electrolyte interface resistance is particularly important for flexible ZABs, where the solid electrolyte is less wettable compared to the liquid electrolyte, so these phenomena also provide ideas for further improvement of ZAB components [85]. 2.4.5 Open circuit voltage test The open-circuit voltage (OCV) in a Zn-air battery is the voltage when it is not connected to any device. At first, when fully charged, it is at its highest potential, representing the maximum power of a battery. As the battery discharges over time, OCV decreases, showing how fast it loses power during storage. If recharged or left unused, OCV can partially or fully recover, revealing how well the battery reactions can be reversed. OCV helps estimate the charge level and health of the battery, and sudden drops can signal safety issues. This data are vital for research and practical use in improving battery designs and durability. 3 Bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts design 3.1 Structure design An ideal bifunctional ORR/OER catalyst must possess the following features: (1) a large surface area and multi-level porous structure to expose more ORR/OER active sites; (2) a highly conductive network structure and three-dimensional (3D) skeleton to expedite mass transport and charge transfer; (3) a high graphitization degree to enhance the corrosion resistance of carbon-based catalysts; (4) a stable gas-liquid-solid three-phase interface to promote the adsorption, dissociation, and electron transfer of reactants. Air electrodes with appropriate hydrophobicity on the surface can supply fast gas and electrolyte transfer pathways, thus leading to decreased ohmic polarization; (5) self-supported integrated electrodes used as air cathodes simplifying the electrode preparation process, eliminating the need for binders and conductive additives. By reducing the impedance at the substrate/electrode interface, the in situ growth can enhance the electronic conductivity, electrocatalytic stability, as well as activity of the electrode [86]. Additionally, flexibility makes them potentially applicable in solid-state air batteries. During the electrochemical process, the oxidation state of metals is prone to change, and metal nanoparticles tend to aggregate, leading to alterations in the structure and activity of catalysts. Under strong polarization, nanoparticles may undergo amorphous phase transition, reducing the stability of the catalyst. During long-term stability tests of ZAB, due to high potentials and strong oxidizing conditions, catalysts may even experience detachment, thus limiting their lifespan. Unveiling the structure of catalysts with controlled architectures necessitates a range of analytical techniques, including X-ray diffraction (XRD) for crystal structures, scanning electron microscope (SEM) for surface morphology, transmission electron microscope (TEM) for atomic-level insights, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) for surface chemistry, and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS), among others. The integration of these methods enables a holistic grasp of the catalyst structure and the consequential impact on catalytic activity. Given this, structure design methods, such as hierarchical structures and surface/interface engineering, offer a range of advantages for designing bifunctional electrocatalysts for flexible zinc-air batteries. These advantages include improved catalytic activity, durability, conductivity, and cost-effectiveness, making them essential strategies in advancing the performance and sustainability of zinc-air battery technology. Therefore, regulating the structure of catalysts can effectively enhance their activity and stability. 3.1.1 Hierarchical structure The electrocatalytic performance is largely determined by the abundance of catalytic active sites and their intrinsic activity, and multi-level structures are generally beneficial for increasing and exposing active sites [87]. Recently, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been widely utilized as precursors and self-templating frameworks for constructing multi-level porous structures in bifunctional catalysts due to their abundant carbon-nitrogen species and regular pore structures. For example, Fu et al. [88] prepared a Co-Mo2N hollow tube composite as an oxygen reaction catalyst through the “MOFs plus MOFs” strategy. However, in the pyrolysis process, the central metal is prone to aggregation, blocking charge transfer channels and reducing active sites. Studies have shown that transition metal nanoparticles encapsulated with graphene layers or carbon nanotubes (CNTs) exhibit excellent ORR/OER performance [89–91]. In the electrocatalytic process, the core-shell structure mitigates nanoparticle aggregation and corrosion. Additionally, the interaction between the carbon layer and metal nanoparticles accelerates electron transfer and oxygen species adsorption-desorption. Therefore, combining MOFs with carbon-coated structures to design rational nanostructures is an effective approach to fabricate bifunctional catalysts. Xia et al. [92] synthesized nitrogen-doped CNTs assembled hollow dodecahedron frameworks (NCNTFs) as bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts by pyrolyzing ZIF-67 under Ar/H2 atmosphere (Fig. 6 a). Recently, using ZIF-67 as a precursor and mixing it with melamine to induce the specific directional growth of CNTs, 3D CNTs with sea urchin-like structures were synthesized (Fig. 6b), which can be applied as efficient catalysts for water splitting and ZAB. The top of the CNTs is encapsulated with cobalt nanoparticles, and this core-shell structure not only enhances the corrosion resistance of cobalt substance but also maximizes the exposure of active sites [93]. It is noteworthy that the synthesis conditions have a significant impact on the structure and morphology of ZIF-67. A rhombic dodecahedral structure can be achieved in a methanol-dominant solution, whereas a leaf-like structure can be prepared in a water-dominant solution. Wang et al. [94] synthesized a Co-N-CNT bifunctional oxygen electrocatalyst using leaf-like Co/Zn bimetallic ZIF as a precursor (Fig. 6c). Zhong et al. [95] used acid-treated carbon cloth (CC) as a substrate to synthesize a 3D self-supported electrocatalyst with a “MOF on MOF” structure by simply altering the reaction medium, which exhibits excellent flexibility and high stability when utilized as the cathode for solid-state ZAB. Moreover, the surface-functionalized melamine sponge (MS) is proved to be beneficial for the nucleation and growth of ZIF-67, forming grafting structures on MS to enhance oxygen reaction activity (Fig. 6d-i) [96]. Electrospinning combined with other auxiliary methods may regulate the activation barrier, holding great potential for the preparation of ORR/OER bifunctional electrocatalysts, especially considering their large-scale synthesis and cost-effective benefit. Guo et al. [97] used low-cost and readily available polyacrylonitrile (PAN) nanofibers as substrates for depositing MOF, resulting in flexible ZABs with CoSA@NCF/CNF bases exhibiting excellent stability and energy storage capability under different folding states. 3.1.2 Surface/interface engineering The impedance caused by the complex gas-liquid-solid three-phase interface and the sluggish ORR kinetics decrease the energy conversion efficiency of ZAB. Multiphase electrocatalytic reactions typically take place at the catalyst interface, and therefore, designing well-defined and stable interfaces can optimize the adsorption of active substances and activate the catalytic reactions [98]. The electrochemical reactions taking place at the three-phase interface are usually divided into the following processes: (1) mass diffusion of active reagents from the electrolyte to the surface of catalyst; (2) electron transfer from the conductive substrate to the active site; (3) adsorption-desorption of reactants at the active site. Additionally, appropriate hydrophobicity at the gas-liquid-solid three-phase interface can facilitate electron transfer and oxygen diffusion to minimize concentration polarization. Researchers proposed a 3D multiphase interface approach to extend the reaction interface into the gas diffusion layer (GDL) (Fig. 7 a) [99]. Water hydrotalcite was grown on one side of carbon paper as a hydrophilic OER catalyst, while the other side was coated with PTFE as a hydrophobic layer. This asymmetric air electrode can provide more active sites, accelerate mass transport processes, and create a dynamically robust reaction interface. Zhou et al. [100] used a similar preparation method to fabricate a superhydrophobic air diffusion electrode, which exhibited an oxygen diffusion coefficient, 5.7 times larger than the conventional system with gas diffusion electrode (GDE). In addition to the three-phase interface of the air electrode, constructing appropriate heterointerfaces can not only regulate the charge transfer between two-phase interfaces but also reduce the energy barrier of reactions by changing the number of active sites and surface binding energy, thus significantly enhancing catalytic activity [101]. However, achieving a highly fused heterojunction of two different metals remains a major challenge, as different metal components tend to grow independently. Currently, most reported heterojunction structures involve converting metal parts into metal composites. The simplest strategy for preparing heterojunction catalysts is post-processing of bimetallic oxides/hydroxides, leading to a phase transformation in situ to produce a compact interface that effectively reduces resistance. For example, Guo et al. [102] prepared a porous NiO/CoN heterojunction nanoarray with abundant oxygen vacancies by controllably nitriding spinel NiCo2O4, thereby enhancing the electrocatalytic activity and stability of ORR/OER. Gilroy et al. [103] have conducted an in-depth review of the design, synthesis, and catalytic performance of bimetallic catalysts, highlighting the significant role of their integrated physicochemical properties for bimetallic catalysts. Transition metals such as Mn and Fe are abundant in reserves and have low costs, exhibiting good ORR activity. On the other hand, Ni and Co species possess excellent conductivity and higher OER catalytic activity. Therefore, integrating them together is a promising approach for preparing bifunctional heterogeneous catalysts. Ji et al. [104] stabilized different metal ions using carboxyl-modified CNTs and prepared Ni/MnO heterostructures on a porous carbon fiber (as shown in Fig. 7b). DFT results revealed that the lattice distortion resulted from the heterointerface changed the electronic structure of Mn, leading to a downward shift of the d-band center of adjacent nickel atoms, making them electron donors. As a result, the oxygen vacancies were formed for the reduction of Mn at the interface by the intense electronic interaction between Ni and Mn. Additionally, the interface structure maintained a low energy state, conferring good stability to the catalyst. Gao et al. [105] utilized bimetallic metal-organic frameworks (Co/Mn-MIL-100) as precursors and constructed numerous Co/MnO hetero-interfaces within a porous graphite carbon through a simple hydrothermal calcination method (as shown in Fig. 7c). The resulting MnO/Co/PGC catalyst exhibited excellent bifunctional oxygen catalytic activity and stability. 3.2 Optimization of active sites The purpose of atom-level regulation is to optimize the electronic structure of active sites, thus promoting suitable adsorption energy for oxygen intermediates, reducing the free energy of the rate-determining step of oxygen electrode reaction, and enhancing the intrinsic activity of the catalyst. Currently, the strategies of atomic doping or etching have been adopted to enhance the catalytic activity of carbon materials [106]. Optimization of active sites in electrocatalysts through methods such as heterogeneous atom doping, monoatomic dispersion, and corrosion engineering offers a range of advantages for designing bifunctional electrocatalysts for flexible zinc-air batteries. These advantages include enhanced catalytic activity, precise control over catalyst properties, high selectivity, long-term stability, efficient resource utilization, reduced overpotential, and compatibility with flexible designs. These methods play a crucial role in advancing the performance and sustainability of zinc-air battery technology. 3.2.1 Heterogeneous atom doping The incorporation of one or more heteroatoms can effectively alter the chemical environment and electronic structure of neighboring carbon atoms in the composite catalysts. The electron transfer between the heteroatoms and adjacent carbon atoms leads to a redistribution of charge in the carbon plane, therefore influencing the adsorption energy of surface oxygen species. Nitrogen, being adjacent to carbon in the periodic table, has similar atomic radii but different electronegativities to carbon (3.04 and 2.55 for nitrogen and carbon, respectively). This characteristic ensures successful doping of the heteroatom without causing the collapse of the carbon framework. The electron redistribution and C-N dipole moment provide active sites for ORR/OER. Consequently, nitrogen-doped nano-carbon materials have attracted significant attention [107,108]. Cheng et al. [109] prepared nitrogen-doped flexible three-dimensional porous carbon microtubes (NCMT) using cotton as the raw material. The NCMT catalyst, with a high degree of graphitization and tightly connected porous tube walls, along with a large content of quaternary and pyridinic nitrogen, demonstrated excellent bifunctional electrocatalytic activity (ΔE = 0.63 V). Similarly, Sun et al. [110] synthesized N-doped graphene as a bifunctional oxygen electrocatalyst, with pyridinic nitrogen selectively doped at the edge sites of graphene as the active sites. For nitrogen-doped carbon-based bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts, the doping content has a significant impact on the electrocatalytic activity. Typically, nitrogen atoms in the dopant act as active sites to enhance catalytic performance. However, the doping process can introduce some defects that disrupt the ideal delocalized electron transfer system and reduce the electrical conductivity. Thus, the nitrogen content needs to strike a delicate balance [111,112]. Yang et al. [113] utilized fermented grape skin to synthesize nitrogen-doped hierarchical porous carbon nanonetworks. They adjusted the N content by regulating the pyrolysis temperature. At the temperature from 600 to 900 °C, the atomic N percentage was reduced from 2.15 to 1.61 at%, leading to a reduction in catalytic activity. In addition to optimizing the nitrogen content, controlling the distribution of N-doped atoms is also essential. Tian et al. [114] reported a representative work as shown in Fig. 8 (a). Compared to conventional bulk nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes (NCNT), the surface-enriched nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes (CNT@NCNT) exposed nitrogen atoms more favorably and thus worked effectively. Considering the different electronic structures and spatial hindrance caused by the doping of different nitrogen atoms, their chemical configurations (pyridinic nitrogen, pyrrolic nitrogen, and quaternary nitrogen) are also crucial in regulating the electrocatalytic performance. Due to the different induction and conjugation effects induced by different nitrogen species, they lead to significant differences in electrocatalytic activity [115,116]. Xia et al. [117] studied the influence of different nitrogen configurations on the intrinsic ORR/OER activity on a nitrogen-doped graphene model through DFT calculations. They proposed that nitrogen-doped armchair and edge carbons served as OER/ORR active sites, respectively. In addition to the N-doping, other heteroatoms can also serve as dopants to induce a redistribution of carbon framework charges, thereby constructing ORR/OER active sites. Researchers have successfully prepared boron/sulfur/phosphorus-doped non-metallic bifunctional catalysts [118–120]. Moreover, both experimental exploration and theoretical calculations have indicated that, compared to single-atom doping, dual-atom doping is more effective in enhancing electrochemical performance, and the synergistic effect between dual heteroatoms is crucial in achieving bifunctional activity. Zhang et al. [121] prepared a nitrogen/phosphorus dual-doped mesoporous foam carbon that exhibited good bifunctional catalytic activity, allowing the assembled ZAB to cycle 600 times at 2 mA cm−2. 3.2.2 Monoatomic dispersion Zhang et al. [122] conducted a pioneering study on the synthesis and application of single-atom electrocatalysts, which has led to the concept “single-atom catalysis” in recent years. By reducing the size of particles to atomic clusters or the single-atom level, both electronic structures and physicochemical properties undergo essential changes. Benefiting from their unique structural features, single-atom catalysts exhibit superior activity, selectivity, and stability compared to conventional particles. In addition to the aforementioned non-metallic doping, introducing transition metals into carbon materials to form M-N-C sites (M representing transition metal atoms) may effectively promote catalytic activity even in the presence of trace amounts of metals [123]. These doped transition metals are usually dispersed atomically and coordinated directly with four dopant atoms (usually C or N) in the same plane, forming single-atom M-N-C sites on the carbon framework [124]. As representative single-atom catalysts, M-N-C catalysts achieve maximized atomic utilization. Furthermore, the interaction between d orbitals of central transition metal atoms and the p electrons of oxygen intermediates favors oxygen molecule adsorption and electron transfer [125,126]. The tunable structure of M-N-C sites provides an opportunity for rational design and precise regulation of the ORR/OER activity, making them promising bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts. Among different transition metals, M-N-C single-atom catalysts centered around Co and Fe have demonstrated excellent oxygen electrocatalytic activity [127–129]. The theoretical calculations [130] revealed that Co-N-C active sites exhibited the highest OER activity and acceptable ORR activity. Compared to M-C-N catalysts centered around other transition metal atoms, Co-N-C catalysts showed the superior bifunctional activity. Moreover, substantial efforts have been devoted to the synthesis routes of Co-N-C catalysts. Li et al. [131], for instance, successfully prepared Co-N-C catalysts by thermally decomposing a pre-designed precursor composed of cobalt-coordinated porphyrin frameworks and graphene hybrids (the synthesis process is shown in Fig. 8b). The catalyst exhibited a certain bifunctional activity (ΔE = 0.87 V). Sun et al. [132] developed a simple “template-sacrifice” strategy, synthesizing multi-level structures of Co-N-C using well-arranged MOFs as precursors, which demonstrated excellent bifunctional activity (ΔE = 0.72 V). In addition to Co-N-C, active sites with M-N-C combined with other central metal atoms also exhibit some bifunctional activities. Following this line, Zhi et al. [133] prepared catalysts with Fe-N-C active sites dispersed in carbon matrix by thermally embedding iron and 2,2′-bipyridine coordinating complexes into the MOF precursors, and they exhibited good catalytic activity (ΔE = 0.76 V). Furthermore, Cheng et al. [134] dexterously introduced ion-coordinated macrocycles as Fe-N4 active sites, and the resulting catalyst exhibited remarkable bifunctional activity (ΔE = 0.66 V). Although significant progress has been made in the preparation of single-atom catalysts, according to the bifunctional volcano plots, it is not possible for M-N4 sites based on a single metal to simultaneously achieve optimal ORR and OER activity. Recently, the geometric structure regulation of M-N-C active sites has received considerable attention, for their direct connection with electronic structures and intrinsic activity [135,136]. To regulate the atoms coordinated directly with the central metals, Mu et al. [137] proposed Co-N x B y active sites (Fig. 8c), where the introduction of boron atoms induced uneven charge distribution, polarizing the central cobalt atoms and promoting oxygen species adsorption, thereby enhancing catalyst activity. In the case of Mn-N-C active sites, Shang et al. [138] proposed that different coordination environments of nitrogen or carbon atoms (Mn-N x C y ) could regulate the d-band center density of Mn atoms and improve ORR/OER activity. Among different chemical coordinations, Mn-N2C2 sites demonstrated the optimal catalytic activity, and further operando X-ray absorption fine structure characterization indicated that Mn2+-N2C2 and Mn4+-N2C2 sites served as the real active sites towards ORR and OER, respectively (Fig. 8d and e). Additionally, the introduction of external metal atoms to form bimetallic active sites has also been proven to be effective in enhancing M-N-C catalytic activity. It is worth noting that while metal single-atom catalysts can make full use of active sites, the performance of ZAB assembled from them during charge and discharge at high current densities is not satisfactory. This may be due to the highly dispersed metal atoms reducing the degree of catalyst crystallinity and affecting the overall electron transfer of single-atom catalysts. Single-atom catalysts supply an ideal model and scientific reference to investigate catalytic mechanisms at the molecular level, making them promising candidates for the next generation of industrial catalysts. 3.2.3 Corrosion engineering Besides the heteroatom doping strategy, ball milling, acid treatment, doping removal, and plasma etching can introduce oxygen-containing functional groups, dangling bonds, defect sites, and vacancies, effectively regulating the electronic properties of neighboring carbon atoms. In recent years, plasma etching technology has been commonly used for synthesizing electrocatalysts, mainly for surface modification and edge and defect formation. Tao et al. [139] confirmed that plasma etching increased the amount of active edge sites, leading to improved electrocatalytic activity of graphene edges. Moreover, since oxygen atoms have large electronegativity, oxygen-containing functional groups can potentially acquire partial electrons from neighboring carbon atoms, redistributing charges on carbon atoms. Positively charged carbon atoms can then serve as active sites, enhancing the adsorption of intermediates in ORR/OER and improving the electrochemical performance of graphene. For example, by plasma etching the surface of carbon fibers to in-situ produce defective graphene, the resulting graphene exhibited high conductivity, a large specific surface area, and more active sites, facilitating mass transfer and thus displaying superior ORR/OER catalytic activity. DFT calculations have further confirmed the importance of various defects created by plasma in oxygen electrocatalysis. The topological defects caused by doping removal strategies will be detailed in subsequent sections. 4 Bifunctional self-supported oxygen electrocatalysts for air cathodes 4.1 Main features and benefits of self-supported bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts While a large number of non-precious metal-based bifunctional powder catalysts, such as alloys, metal sulfides/nitrides/phosphides, and MOFs, have been reported for several decades, the fabrication of catalytic electrodes often requires the addition of polymer binders, which inevitably leads to catalyst microstructure destruction, surface area reduction, and easy catalyst shedding during cycling [22,140–145]. An essential tactic for the development of ZABs in this respect is the creation of standalone oxygen electrodes from readily accessible and inexpensive materials in order to avoid the use of polymer binders and to achieve high catalytic activity and stability [97,146]. Potential flexible cathodes mostly possess the following features: (1) remarkable electrical conductivity to facilitate charge transfer; (2) proper porosity to guarantee better oxygen diffusion; (3) outstanding bifunctional catalytic activity; (4) proper hydrophilicity and hydrophobicity to form a stable three-phase interface. In addition, self-supported air electrodes often have better mechanical flexibility and can be bent, folded, or curled to meet the practical needs of flexible ZABs [147–150]. Compared with powder catalysts, firstly, air electrodes with direct self-supported structures can avoid the time-consuming coating process of polymer binders, which is more conducive to mass production and lower cost. Secondly, the robust contact between the catalyst and conductive substrate enables faster charge transfer and greater mechanical stability for excellent long-term durability during charge/discharge cycles. Finally, a 3D structure of the self-supported electrocatalyst can provide a larger specific surface area and exposes more active sites than conventional flat catalyst coatings, thus improving the catalytic activity [151–154]. 4.2 Preparation of self-supported oxygen electrocatalysts According to the reported designs of self-supported air cathodes, catalysts are currently prepared on flexible or rigid substrates by four main methods or a combination of them: hydrothermal/solvothermal methods, electrostatic spinning, electrodeposition, and floating-catalyst chemical vapor deposition (FCCVD) [27,155–158]. The resulting free-standing air electrodes possess good flexibility as well as electrochemical properties. 4.2.1 Carbon-based substrate supported air cathodes Due to the advantages of superior electrical conductivity, chemical stability, and light weight of carbon-based materials such as carbon paper, carbon fibers, and carbon nanotubes, they have been commonly applied in flexible ZABs [156,159–161]. If a carbon cloth woven or stacked with carbon fibers is used as the substrate, it will show better flexibility and sufficient porosity, and the hydrophilicity/hydrophobicity of the carbon material can be adjusted by the oxygen-containing groups [162]. Table 1 lists the newly reported bifunctional air electrodes for rechargeable ZABs that are supported by carbon-based substrates. Carbon nanotubes are recognized as one of the ideal conductive supports for flexible self-supported air electrodes due to their large surface area, excellent electrical conductivity, and remarkable mechanical strength [158,170–172]. Yan et al. [23] developed a supercritical carbon dioxide (SCCO2)-assisted post-annealing method by constructing an array of vertically well-aligned carbon nanotubes consisting of oxygen vacancy-rich NiFe nanoparticles that could act as efficient oxygen electrocatalysts, as depicted in Fig. 9 (a and b). The structure can offer the active framework and channels required for mass transfer of intermediary ions. The SCCO2 treatment improved the hydrophobicity of VACNTs and promoted metal oxide growth on its surface to maximize the exposure of active sites. Due to these synergistic advantages, the obtained Ni@CNTs exhibited excellent oxygen electrocatalytic activity and stability. As shown in Fig. 9(c), ΔE = E j=10(OER) − E 1/2(ORR) for NiFeO x @VACNTs was 0.74 V which was closed to that of Pt/C + IrO2 (ΔE = 0.71 V), indicating a better bifunctional catalytic activity. Meng et al. [163] described a method to partially anchor monatomic Fe-N x onto freestanding, high-quality, and flexible SWCNT films via fluorination and defluorination/ammoniation (Fig. 9d and e). The obtained SAFe-SWCNT electrocatalyst showed a high density of Fe-N x active sites while maintaining the high crystallinity, excellent flexibility, and integrity of SWCNT. Compared to commercial Pt/C + Ir/C, the single-atom Fe-N x loaded single-walled carbon nanotube films demonstrated greater catalytic activity (Fig. 9f). To immobilize nanotube joints, Zeng et al. [158] initially produced lightweight CNT aerogel films covered with amorphous carbon using floating catalytic chemical vapor deposition (FCCVD) and CVD. To subsequently create Co3O4/N-CNT aerogel films, cobalt oxide particles were hydrothermally grown on electrochemically activated CNT hydrogel films containing rich hydroxyl and carboxyl groups (Fig. 9g-i). The outcomes demonstrated the high strength and ability to fold without breaking the carbon-welded aerogel sheets (Fig. 9j). During the hydrothermal process, nitrogen-containing groups on CNTs might coordinate with cobalt ions, potentially forming Co-N-C bonds that were essential for improving ORR performance. Although the onset potential of the composite electrode was slightly higher than that of Pt/C, its limiting current density was comparable to that of Pt/C and is 1.8 times that of CNT aerogel, 1.1 times that of N-CNT, and 2 times that of Co3O4 nanoparticles, respectively (Fig. 9k). In addition, the potential of the composite aerogel at 10 mA cm−2 was 1.7 V, which was much lower than that of pristine CNT aerogel, N-CNT aerogel, and pure Co3O4. These results indicated that the Co3O4/N-CNT composite aerogel was an efficient bifunctional oxygen electrocatalyst. Freestanding films constructed from carbon nanofibers (CNFs) and derivatives have also been well studied as self-supported air cathodes [84,173,174]. Yang et al. [165] created 1D CNFs embedded with Fe/Zn-ZIFs using the electrostatic spinning process, which were subsequently interleaved to build 3D carbon film precursors (denoted as Fe/Zn-ZIFs/thiourea/PAN films). Afterward, the carbon fiber membranes were further pyrolyzed in Ar and Ar/NH3 gases to obtain flexible and independent Fe/SNCFs-NH3 membranes, generating a large number of highly exposed Fe-N4/C active sites, numerous micropores in the carbon skeleton derived from Zn evaporation, and optimized heteroatom doping (Fig. 10 a and b). The experimental results and theoretical calculations revealed that the doped S played a key role in the regulation of the catalytic activity of ORR and OER. As shown in Fig. 10(c), Fe/SNCFs-NH3 exhibited a half-wave potential of 0.89 V, which was better than commercial Pt/C (0.86 V). Its Tafel slope of 70.82 mV dec−1 was much smaller than that of Fe/NCFs-NH3 (96.15 mV dec−1). The EIS curve further demonstrated that the S doping improved the reaction kinetics with the lower charge transfer resistance (Fig. 10d). Additionally, Fe/SNCFs-NH3 had a considerably lower overpotential than Fe/NCFs-NH3, indicating that S doping has enhanced OER activity (Fig. 10e). There have been numerous similar reports of electrospun fibers modified with metal ions. For example, Wang et al. [161] co-electrospun pre-designed ZnFeCo-NC precursors along with electrospun polymer PAN to produce flexible CNF films with uniformly distributed diatomic FeN3-CoN3 sites (denoted as Fe1Co1-CNF) after pre-oxidation and graphitization (Fig. 10f). The aberration-corrected high-angle circular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) results revealed that the metal constituents were widely dispersed (Fig. 10g). Compared with Fe1-CNF, Co1-CNF, and CNF, Fe1Co1-CNF showed the smallest ΔE of 0.86 V which was close to Pt/C + RuO2 (0.85 V), indicating the key role of the bimetallic site Fe-Co in boosting the ORR/OER activity. Based on theoretical calculations and the fact that the intermediate OH* would spontaneously adsorb to the diatomic metal sites during ORR/OER, the diatomic Fe-Co sites in Fe1Co1-CNF were modeled as FeCoN6(OH). The Fe and Co atoms in FeCoN6(OH) acted as the active sites for ORR and OER, respectively, as observed from the volcano plot (Fig. 10h), which indicated that the Fe site in FeCoN6(OH) showed the lowest η ORR = 0.27 V and the Co site showed the lowest η OER = 0.28 V. These results were consistent with the experimental findings. These researches also illustrate the significance of bimetallic sites in catalytic activity. Chen et al. [164] developed a scalable synthetic strategy to first synthesize 1D core-shell polymer fibers by coaxial electrospun technique, followed by in situ growing of leaf-like zeolite imidazole framework (ZIF-L) on NiFe@PAN PF by a straightforward hydrothermal method, and finally carbonization to obtain three-layer flexible 3D-like Janus hollow nanofibers separated by thin walls. The synthesized Janus nanofibers showed excellent mechanical flexibility with an inner layer consisting of nitrogen-doped nanoribbon-loaded NiFe alloy particles and leaf-like Co-N nanosheets anchored to the carbon layer on the outer wall. The NiFe@C@Co CNFs displayed improved bifunctional catalytic activity (ΔE = 0.73 V) as compared to the Pt/C + RuO2 (0.749 V) because of the plentiful active sites and short ion diffusion routes. Carbon cloth (CC)/carbon fabric (CF) is considered as one of the ideal substrates for flexible ZABs due to its outstanding mechanical flexibility, superior electrical conductivity, high stability, 3D microstructure properties, easy modification, and lightweight [30,175–179]. Various strategies have been reported for the preparation of bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts using carbon fabrics as substrates. For example, to construct well-crystallized ultrathin mesoporous Co3O4 layers, Chen et al. [166] initially created a quick and easy electrodeposition procedure to manufacture ultrathin cobalt hydroxide nanofilms with high contact areas on the surface of carbon fibers in flexible carbon fabrics followed by annealing at 400 °C in air. The majority of previously described Co3O4 were grown on a conductive carrier with only a tiny region, namely the root of deposits, to be in contact with the carrier, thus producing a nanofilm with weak adhesion and simple aggregation. The inclusion of HOCH2CH2OH in the preparation procedure could ensure the production of a homogeneous ultrathin layer of cobalt hydroxide with the greatest possible surface area on the surface of the carbon fibers. The cross-section TEM image showed the strong contrast between the carbon fibers and the Co3O4 ultrathin nanosheets. Atomic force microscopy (AFM) was used to determine the thickness of the Co3O4 layer, which was found to be roughly 4.8 nm. The activity of ORR and OER of the ultrathin Co3O4/CC electrode was more than an order of magnitude higher when compared to that of commercial Co3O4/CC electrodes due to the high utilization of active materials and rapid charge transfer. This approach significantly enhances the efficiency of ORR and OER by adopting CC substrate. Recently, MOFs have begun to be used as precursors in the production of carbon-based electrocatalysts with evenly distributed active sites and good electrical conductivity. In particular, the metal component can be changed into metal nanoparticles, metal compound nanoparticles, or atomic metals doped in a porous graphitic carbon matrix after high-temperature pyrolysis of MOFs [93,180–184]. Liu et al. [167] first synthesized Co-MOF nanosheet arrays on carbon cloth and then used a facile carbon-acidification process to prepare single-atom-anchored electrocatalysts, namely NC-Co SA. The removal of excess Co metal clusters by acidification generated additional pores and increased the active surface area. Additionally, NC-Co SA had a large amount of exposed Co-N x sites on its surface, which could facilitate oxygen adsorption and mass transfer. As a consequence, NC-Co SA showed a lower OER overpotential and a greater ORR saturation current with an impressive ΔE = 0.72 V. Similarly, Guan et al. [168] used Co-MOF nanosheets grown on carbon cloth as precursors and then adopted a combined cobalt-based carbon-oxidation process to create a hierarchically structured catalyst (denoted as NC-Co3O4) with a special composition of irregular hollow Co3O4 nanospheres embedded in an array of nitrogen-doped carbon nanowalls (Fig. 11 a and b). In this case, the carbon-induced nanoscale Kockendall effect was responsible for the shift from Co nanoparticles to hollow Co3O4 nanospheres. Aberration-corrected STEM and electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) were used to further investigate the morphological features and reveal the structural evolution mechanism. It was shown that the single-crystal Co nanoparticles were embedded in carbon nanowall arrays with their surfaces covered by several onion-like graphite layers, while the shell remained wrapped by graphite layers during the oxidative transformation into hollow Co3O4 nanospheres and the carbon coating could be retained to a certain extent (Fig. 11c and d). However, the shape of the hollow spheres was irregular due to the different thicknesses of the carbon shells at different locations. These nanospheres were well integrated with the nitrogen-doped carbon arrays to achieve effective bifunctional catalysis for ORR and OER. As shown in Fig. 11(e and f), the half-wave potential of optimized NC-Co3O4-90 was 0.87 V, which was lower than that of Pt/C (0.91 V). In addition, NC-Co3O4-90 required a lower overpotential (358 mV) than Co3O4 (371 mV) and NC-Co (373 mV), indicating that the combination of NC and Co3O4 could produce a synergistic effect. These findings highlight the potential of MOF-derived materials in electrocatalysis. Catalysts grown on carbon cloth allow for the tuning of morphological structures in addition to the adjustment of components [29,175,185,186]. Beside the previously mentioned nanosheet morphology, the needle-like structure is also appealing. An example is the NiCo2S4 needle-like heterostructure arrays with defect-rich nitrogen-doped graphene quantum dots (GQDs) grown on carbon cloth using a two-step hydrothermal, electrodeposition and calcination method reported by Liu al. [169] as depicted in Fig. 11(g). The N-GQDs were evenly anchored on the NiCo2S4 nanowires as shown in the HRTEM images in Fig. 11(h and i). This resulted in more active sites, better electrical conductivity, and a suppression of structural changes throughout the catalytic process. As shown in Fig. 11(j and k), N-GQDs/NiCo2S4/CC showed a more positive half-wave potential (E 1/2 = 0.86 V) for ORR and a smaller potential of 30 mA cm−2 (E j=30 = 1.57 V) for OER among all samples. N-GQDs/NiCo2S4/CC also demonstrated the best bifunctional activity with ΔE = 0 0.71 V when compared to the contrast samples, and it was much better than the commercial catalyst Pt/C + IrO2 (ΔE = 0.85 V). The inclusion of N-GQDs and its interaction with NiCo2S4, which enhanced the active sites and promoted the adsorption/desorption of O* and OOH*, was primarily responsible for the good catalytic performance of N-GQDs/NiCo2S4/CC. The distinct 3D structure also made it possible for quick electron transport and diffusion of reactants/products, which lowered the reaction overpotential. 4.2.2 Metal substrate supported air cathodes The superior electrical conductivity and great ductility of metallic materials make them appealing choices as substrates for flexible cathodes. Without the use of conductive materials or binders, direct bottom-up growth or deposition of active catalysts on metal substrates can considerably improve the physical and electrical contact between the electrode assemblies, hence enhancing the device performance [187–189]. Table 2 summarizes the recently reported bifunctional air electrodes supported by metal substrates for self-supported rechargeable ZABs. Metal foil, including Ni, Ti, and Cu foils, is a class of conductive substrates that are widely used in the preparation of 3D air electrodes [201–203]. Lambert et al. [191] synthesized nanostructured mesoporous Ni-doped cobalt-based spinel oxide films (Ni x Co3− x O4) directly on Ni foil by electrodeposition-thermal annealing method to produce bifunctional catalysts for reversible oxygen electrocatalysis. Fig. 12 (a) reveals the nanosheets morphology of Ni0.6Co2.4O4 and the change of color in the synthetic process. The presence of Ni significantly improved the ORR performance of Ni0.6Co2.4O4 films compared to Co3O4. As shown in Fig. 12(b), the electrocatalytic performance of Ni0.6Co2.4O4 film on Ni foil, Ni0.6Co2.4O4 powder removed from Ni foil, and Ni0.6Co2.4O4 powder mixed with Vulcan carbon and Nafion binder was compared. The films could be used as promising bifunctional catalysts and this was mainly attributed to the tight contact of Ni x Co3− x O4 with the Ni substrate, high surface area, mesoporous structure, and good electrical conductivity. Amiinu et al. [190] reported an advanced Co-N x /C nanorod arrays derived from atomic 3D ZIF nanocrystal grown on titanium substrates by a simple hydrothermal-pyrolytic process (Fig. 12c and d). Better Zn-air cell performance was derived from the improved bifunctional oxygen electrocatalytic activity (Fig. 12e, ΔE = 0.65 V), which was primarily related to the interaction of adequate Co-N coupling centers, unique morphology, adequate porosity, and large surface area. Metal mesh (such as stainless steel mesh, copper mesh, iron mesh, etc.) is considered as a good flexible support substrate because of its excellent electrical conductivity, good mechanical strength, and low cost [83,204,205]. Fu et al. [45] reported a bifunctional oxygen electrocatalyst with 3D nanostructured arrays mimicking human hair morphology (Fig. 13 a and b). This electrocatalysts could be prepared by coupling nitrogen-doped multi-walled carbon nanotubes (NCNT) directly into stainless steel mesh network by electrodeposition of iron oxide seeds and CVD, followed by electrodeposition and annealing to grow Co3O4 nanometal onto NCNT to form scale-like Co3O4-NCNT/SS nanocomponent arrays similar to those found in human hairs. The tight interfacial contact between Co3O4 and NCNT created a low-resistance channel for high charge transfer during ORR and OER. In the meantime, after decorating with NCNT, the hydrophilicity of Co3O4 was decreased, which would in turn enhance oxygen diffusion inside the electrode during ORR. Thanks to the synergistic effect between Co3O4 and NCNT as well as the robust and flexible hair-like structure, Co3O4-NCNT/SS exhibited excellent ORR and OER activities. The stability test results showed that the activity of Co3O4-NCNT/SS in alkaline environment decayed more slowly than Pt/C-SS and Ir-C/SS, manifesting better ORR and OER stability (Fig. 13c). As shown in Fig. 13(d), the interconnected macropore structure on the surface of Co3O4-NCNT/SS remained almost unchanged after 7 h of OER stability test, which was crucial for the long-life cycle of rechargeable ZABs. Liu et al. [192] fabricated flexible self-supported integrated bifunctional SSM/Co4N/CoNC oxygen electrocatalysts directly on stainless steel mesh (SSM) by a simple scalable synthesis strategy (Fig. 13e). First, SSM was immersed in cobalt nitrate hexahydrate and urea solution, and uniformly distributed nanosheets were grown on SSM by hydrothermal reaction. Then, Co2+ in the nanosheets supplied enough nucleation sites for the formation of ZIF-67 nanoparticles, which were grown in situ on the nanosheets. Finally, pyrolysis at low temperature was performed on the precursors with melamine to produce SSM/Co4N/CoNC air electrodes. Compared with SSM/CoNC obtained by growing ZIF-67 directly on SSM, SSM/Co4N/CoNC exhibited a higher mass transfer capacity and more exposed active sites. Due to the hierarchical porous structure, abundant active sites, high electronic conductivity, and synergistic interaction between Co4N and Co-N-C (Fig. 13f), the resulting integrated electrodes exhibited impressive ORR and OER activities when compared to Co4N/CoNC. The retention of the hierarchical integrated structure in SSM/Co4N/CoNC after 1000 cycles revealed the advantages of the self-supported structure (Fig. 13g), which enabled effective mass transfer, promoted reaction kinetics, and prevented the active material from falling off from the SSM. The ΔE for SSM/Co4N/CoNC was 0.67 V, which was lower than that for RuO2 (0.86 V) and Pt/C (0.77 V) (Fig. 13h). Metal foams, such as nickel foam (NF) and copper foam, exhibited outstanding electrical conductivity and highly porous structures that can facilitate rapid electron transfer and electrolyte penetration [206,207]. The commonly used technological procedures for loading active materials on metal foam substrates include electrodeposition, hydrothermal/solvent thermal growth, chemical deposition, and so on [198,208–210]. For example, Jiang et al. [193] seeded ZnCo-hexamine (HMT) bimetallic complex frameworks with layered structures directly on nickel foam substrates by successive chemical deposition and ion exchange (Fig. 14 a). This reaction was accompanied by a color change from white to purple on the nickel foam surface. In the presence of acetonitrile, a high level of nitrogen-doped CNT was then sprouted in situ from the highly dispersed cobalt seeds by CVD, forming an ordered multidimensional array of MPZ-CC@CNT assembled by carbon nanoridges (Fig. 14b–e). Since there are not many “prohibited zones” in the MPZ-CC@CNT arrays, reactants and intermediates could readily accessed to the active sites with diffusion shuttle pathways, speeding up the reaction rates. The MPZ-CC@CNT significantly improved the ORR and OER performance, and the current was 10–50 times higher than that of the comparison sample (Fig. 14f and g). The electrochemical impedance spectrum also showed that MPZ-CC@CNT had a lower internal resistance and electrochemical polarization due to the reduced “prohibited zones”, which was more favorable for mass transfer at the interfaces of oxygen, electrolyte, and catalyst (Fig. 14h). Spinel Co3O4 is one of the most competitive bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts. It contains two different functional Co ions, where the tetrahedral Co2+ ions form μ-OOH, which directly accelerates the OER process. On the other hand, Co3+ ions occupy octahedral positions with polymorphs and combine with O2 to form oxygen intermediates on the catalyst surface during ORR process. However, the super strong interaction between low spin Co3+ ions and oxygen intermediates will lead to a reduced ORR rate [211,212]. In order to reduce the surface activity of Co3O4 on oxygen intermediates, a reliable method is to introduce metal ions with low oxygen intermediate coordination ability. This has been demonstrated by Xu et al. [146], in which (Ni, Co)3O4 nanosheets were grown directly on nickel foam by a simple electrodeposition-coupled chemical oxidation process (Fig. 15 a). As shown in Fig. 15(b and c), (Ni, Co)3O4@Ni-foam showed a smaller potential of 1.41 V at 10 mA cm−2 for OER and a more positive half-wave potential for ORR (E 1/2 = 0.84 V) that was superior to Pt/C + IrO2 (E 10 = 1.48 V, E 1/2 = 0.81 V). These outcomes were consistent with the results from DFT calculations. As expected, both physical measurements and DFT calculations showed that the (Ni, Co)3O4@Ni-foam had a low binding energy, abundant valence states, and a high specific surface area, hence creating more active centers and increasing the reaction rate. Ni doping reduced the surface activity of Co3O4 towards O*, OH*, and OOH* species and avoided direct dissociation on the surface, thus reducing the OER/ORR overpotential (Fig. 15d). Wu et al. [213] previously described an innovative method for the preparation of self-supported air electrodes by simply pressing two NF@Co3− x Ni x O4 and one SS@Co3O4 together to establish NS@Co3− x Ni x O4/Co3O4 nanowire arrays for dense and interconnected flexible electrodes (Fig. 15e). These electrodes could be made by either hydrothermal or calcination techniques using nickel foam (NF) and stainless steel (SS) mesh. Both methods would give electrodes with needle-like array morphology as shown in Fig. 15(f–h). As shown in Fig. 15(i and j), NF@Ni3− x Co x O4 showed the best ORR performance. For OER, SS and SS@Co3O4 showed better catalytic performance in the low potential window, and their overlap suggested that the addition of Co3O4 did not change the OER catalytic performance of the iron-based SS alloy. In the high potential window, NF@Ni3− x Co x O4 showed the best OER catalytic performance, requiring a overpotential of only 310 mV at a current density of only 10 mA cm−2. The prepared electrodes could fully utilize the sandwich structure to facilitate the reversible Faraday redox reaction from CoNi-O to CoNi-O-OH, leading to excellent ORR/OER performance. This was made possible by the distinctive composite structure of NS@Co3− x Ni x O4/Co3O4, the high loading per unit volume of active catalyst, and the inherent high OER activity of SS. This technology certainly has provided a new strategy for hybrid electrochemical energy storage devices as well as self-supported air electrodes. 5 Applications of bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts in flexible Zn-air batteries Bifunctional oxygen electrocatalyst performance may be assessed using Zn-air battery construction and performance testing. Currently, sandwich/flat-type and cable-type are the two most popular layouts for flexible ZABs. Sandwich-type electrodes consist of two solid substrate layers and the active electrocatalyst layer sandwiched between them. The sandwich-type structure offers excellent flexibility, high surface area for electrochemical reactions, even distribution of active materials, and an intrinsic connection that ensures mechanical stability while allowing deformation without delamination.
