Cable-type electrodes consist of a flexible core (often a conductive wire) surrounded by an electrocatalyst layer. Cable-type electrodes, typically lightweight and capable of being tightly wound or coiled for space-saving in compact battery designs, maintain their structural integrity by achieving an intrinsic connection through a strong bond between the flexible core and surrounding electrocatalyst layer, enabling deformation while preserving electrical connectivity. Both types of electrodes aim to combine mechanical flexibility with effective electrocatalysis, but also they achieve these goals through different structural configurations. The choice between them depends on specific application requirements, such as the need for extreme flexibility, lightweight design, or efficient use of space. In addition to the sandwich and cable types, there are several other flexible electrode structures available for zinc-air batteries, including mesh-type, textile-based, hybrid structures, 3D architectures, and printed electrodes. Table 3 highlights some of the most recent array bifunctional catalysts that have been made for flexible ZABs. Besides, in the design of flexible electrodes and cells for zinc-air batteries, several fundamental considerations and criteria should be incorporated. These include factors such as mechanical flexibility, electrochemical performance, electrical conductivity, stability, material selection, scalability, safety, and integration into flexible cells. These criteria collectively form a comprehensive framework to guide the development of flexible electrodes and cells, balancing electrochemical performance, mechanical flexibility, and sustainability. 5.1 Applications in sandwich-type flexible ZABs A sandwich-type flexible ZAB mainly consists of a stack of collector, an air cathode, solid electrolyte, and a zinc foil. This type of flexible ZAB has certain flexibility that allows it to be bent, folded, and stretched, and demonstrates some practical application prospects [3,85]. For example, Sumboja et al. [30] grew uniform and thin MnO x layers on a graphene-coated carbon substrate by an impregnation process. This directly grown integrated electrode reduced the contact resistance at the carbon/catalyst interface and improved the power density of ZABs. The cross-linked polyacrylic acid (PAA) base was chosen as the solid-state electrolyte to form a high-performance foldable all-solid-state rechargeable ZAB (Fig. 16 a). Due to the smaller footprint of the folded type, the current per unit area was higher, resulting in a higher power density of 32 mW cm−2 than that in the flat state (18 mW cm−2). This ZAB exhibited good stability with minimal performance degradation even after continuous and repeated folding and unfolding for more than 100 times (Fig. 16b and c). Xu et al. [29] constructed a co-doped Fe-Co4N@NC nanosheet array air cathode derived from ZIF precursors on flexible carbon cloth, and the assembled flexible solid-state ZAB is shown in Fig. 16(d). The Fe-Co4N@NC-based battery exhibited a peak power density of 72 mW cm−2, which was better than Pt/C + RuO2 (52 mW cm−2) (Fig. 16e). In addition, the charge and discharge voltages showed almost no drop upon bending to an angle of 0°, 30°, and 60°, exhibiting better cycling durability (Fig. 16f). Pan et al. [217] obtained CuCo2S4 nanosheets@nitrogen-doped carbon nanofiber films by an electrostatic spinning and in situ vulcanization process. These films could be directly used as the cathode of a quasi-solid-state ZAB (Fig. 16g). The quasi-solid-state ZAB assembled by electrodeposition of Zn nanosheets on CNT films as anodes could sustain an open-circuit voltage of 1.46 V for 20 h and had an excellent specific capacity of 896 mA h g−1 Zn (corresponding to an energy density of 65.2 W h kg−1 by weight) as well as excellent cycling stability (Fig. 16h). In addition, the specific capacity was maintained at 93.62% after 1000 cycles of bending from 0° to 180°, again demonstrating the excellent mechanical stability of the battery and showing its potential for application in portable wearable devices. To evaluate the feasibility of the ZAB, two ZABs were connected in series or parallel, respectively demonstrating an increase in voltage and current (Fig. 16i and j). In addition, as depicted in Fig. 16(k and l), three series ZABs could power light-emitting diodes (LEDs) at different bending levels, indicating the excellent flexibility and durability of these ZABs. 5.2 Applications in cable-type flexible ZABs A cable-type flexible zinc-air battery usually consists of a central zinc strip, an intermediate layer of polymer electrolyte, and an externally wound flexible air electrode [31]. A flexible air cathode (denoted as Co4N/CNW/CC) composed of a pearl necklace-like ZIF-67/polypyrrole (PPy) nanofiber network rooted on carbon cloth by pyrolysis was first proposed and demonstrated by Meng et al. [156]. Thanks to the synergistic effect of Co4N and Co-N-C and the stable conductive network structure, the cable-type ZAB based on Co4N/CNW/CC, as shown in Fig. 17 (a), exhibited good rechargeability performance at current densities of 0.5 and 1 mA cm−2. The ZAB also showed excellent stability without significant voltage changes even under continuous bending at 12-min intervals (Fig. 7b and c). In addition, the cells could be bent, folded, and twisted to different degrees, and such flexible properties have endowed them with great potential for wearable electronic devices. Guan et al. [28] synthesized unique hybrid Co/CoN x modified carbon nanoarray catalysts using MOF precursors, which could be directly used as flexible air cathodes (Fig. 17d). NC-Co/CoN x was prepared as both cable-type and sandwich-type flexible ZABs. It was found that the cable-type cells showed a narrower charge/discharge voltage gap with enhanced reversibility (Fig. 17e). In addition, the maximum discharge current density was 344.7 mA cm−2, which was about 2.5 times higher than that of the sandwich type; its peak power density was 104.0 mW cm−2, which was also much larger than that of the sandwich type cell (41.5 mW cm−2) (Fig. 17f). Connecting two cable-type cells in series could power LEDs at flat and 90°-bent configurations, demonstrating their potential applications in practical energy storage devices. A 3D hierarchical self-supported electrode consisting of Co nano-islands and Co-N-C nanosheets rooted on a carbon felt was reported by Peng et al. [27]. The cable-type solid-state ZAB prepared by connecting three in series could power LEDs (Fig. 17g and h). It could be bent continuously and repeatedly for 9 h at a current density of 5 mA cm−2 without any significant change in the voltage, thus confirming its excellent mechanical stability (Fig. 17i). Based on the above, cable-type ZABs are characterized by their elongated and flexible design, making them suitable for various applications where bending and flexibility are essential. They excel in conforming to irregular shapes and can be integrated into wearable devices or textiles. However, their unique form factor may present challenges in terms of scalability and manufacturing complexity. Sandwich-type ZABs, on the other hand, offer a more compact and stackable design, which can simplify production and assembly processes. However, they may not be adaptable to highly flexible applications. Future research directions for flexible ZABs should prioritize addressing the specific challenges associated with these designs, such as dendrite formation, mechanical durability, and the development of flexible, and stable electrode materials. Additionally, research should focus on improving energy and power density while maintaining flexibility, optimizing manufacturing processes for scalability, and exploring applications in fields such as wearable electronics, IoT devices, and flexible energy storage systems. By carefully addressing these aspects, flexible ZABs can realize their full potential and become valuable contributors to the future of portable and wearable technology. 6 Summary and outlook Rechargeable zinc-air batteries stand out as one of the most promising battery technologies, owing to their high theoretical specific energy, cost-effectiveness, eco-friendliness, and operational safety [218]. Among these, self-supported flexible solid-state ZABs have garnered considerable attention from researchers due to their immense practical potential in the portable and wearable electronic device markets. In this comprehensive review, we have systematically elucidated the operational principles of ZABs and highlighted recent advancements in the growth of advanced nanoarray bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts with diverse morphologies on flexible conducting substrates. Despite the remarkable ORR and OER performance exhibited by these array catalysts, it is imperative to address several outstanding challenges that currently hinder the practical realization of flexible ZABs. Rational design of bifunctional electrocatalysts. The primary challenge ahead lies in the development of more efficient and durable bifunctional electrocatalysts. Despite significant progress, the catalytic mechanisms of self-supported catalysts have yet to be thoroughly explored. Many highly efficient catalysts have been discovered serendipitously or through performance-oriented methods that are often time-consuming and challenging to control. To advance our understanding of catalyst behavior in both the ORR and OER, it is imperative to employ in situ techniques and multi-scale simulation calculations. These approaches can provide insights into the catalytic mechanism, the identification of true catalytic active sites, and the elucidation of decay mechanisms. Therefore, integrating theoretical calculations with experimental results for structural adjustments and compositional tuning represents a promising strategy for designing more efficient bifunctional electrocatalysts. Engineering of substrate supports. ORR occurs at the three-phase interface, involving gaseous oxygen, liquid electrolyte, and solid catalyst. In a typical air electrode, there is a hydrophobic GDL combined with a moderately hydrophilic catalyst. The GDL serves as both a substrate support for the catalyst and a conduit for oxygen diffusion. The catalyst layer itself comprises a bifunctional electrocatalyst, a carbon conductive agent, and a binder [3]. However, when adapting this conventional air electrode for flexible ZABs, the use of a rigid substrate becomes impractical. While integrated air electrodes eliminate the need for binders and additives, the choice of a suitable substrate remains crucial, considering factors like conductivity, chemical/mechanical stability, and weight. Presently, integrated electrodes primarily rely on carbon and metal materials, each with its own drawbacks. Carbon-based electrodes are susceptible to corrosion, while metal-based ones increase weight, reducing battery energy density due to their higher density [219–222]. Consequently, there is a pressing need to explore and modify lightweight and corrosion-resistant substrates. Additionally, simplifying the synthetic process to facilitate mass production while optimizing catalyst performance is imperative, especially when considering practical applications are the ultimate research goal. Interface engineering. In the pursuit of high-performance and durable ZABs, interface engineering between the catalyst and the substrate support emerges as a pivotal factor. The interface acts as a bridge connecting the electrochemical activity of catalysts to the mechanical and structural stability of substrates. Effective interface engineering optimizes catalyst-substrate interactions, ensuring not only enhanced catalytic activity but also long-term stability. By tailoring this interface, researchers can mitigate issues such as catalyst detachment, corrosion, and structural degradation, which are often encountered in ZABs. Moreover, it opens the door to innovative strategies for boosting ZAB efficiency and extending their operational lifespan. Besides, effective interface engineering in ZABs involves the deliberate design and modification of the interfaces between the catalyst, substrate support, and electrolyte to mitigate interfacial resistance, which will enhance the performance of ZABs. As we venture into the future of ZAB development, understanding and harnessing the potential of interface engineering will remain central to realizing the full potential of these promising energy storage devices. Computational technology. High-throughput computational technology advances catalyst design for ZABs by providing a systematic and efficient means to explore the vast design space of catalyst materials. It allows researchers to predict the electrochemical performance of various catalyst candidates, including their activity, selectivity, and stability, without the need for time-consuming experimental trials. This approach not only accelerates the development process but also offers insights into novel catalyst structures and compositions that can significantly enhance ZAB performance. Furthermore, high-throughput computational technology fosters a deeper understanding of the structure-performance relationships governing catalysis, paving the way for the rational design of catalysts tailored to the specific needs of ZABs. As a result, it plays a pivotal role in shaping the future of ZAB technology, making it more efficient, sustainable, and accessible. Performance of solid-state electrolytes. One of the fundamental challenges in the development of flexible ZABs is the design of safe and environmentally friendly SSEs that possess superior flexibility, water retention capabilities, mechanical stability, and high ionic conductivity [223]. In aqueous ZABs, the catalyst can directly contact with the electrolyte, facilitating efficient electrochemical reactions. However, in the context of solid-state flexible ZABs, the quasi-solid electrolyte exhibits poor wettability, limiting the reactions at the three-phase interface and substantially increasing interfacial resistance for OH− transport on the catalyst surface compared to aqueous systems [3]. This results in undesirable high overpotentials and low current rates. Therefore, it becomes imperative to engineer solid electrolytes with microporous structures capable of storing an ample supply of hydroxide ions, while demonstrating high selectivity and mechanical stability. Presently, quasi-solid electrolytes, especially alkaline gel electrolytes that encapsulate alkaline aqueous solutions within a polymer matrix, find wide application in flexible ZABs due to their inherent flexibility [82,224]. However, over time, alkaline gel electrolytes tend to lose some of their stretching properties, potentially leading to safety concerns related to KOH solution leakage [225,226]. Additionally, issues such as dehydration can compromise the chemical stability and ionic conductivity of gel electrolytes [227]. Hence, there is a compelling need to explore alternative non-alkaline gel electrolytes characterized by high water retention, mechanical stability, and investigate other all-solid electrolyte options. Besides, Zn-air batteries using neutral electrolytes are also important in energy storage and research. Neutral electrolyte-based batteries have advantages like improved safety and compatibility with certain applications due to lower corrosion risk compared to alkaline electrolytes. They are useful in various fields such as portable electronics and remote sensors, where their reliability and longer lifespan are valuable. Therefore, Zn-air batteries with neutral electrolytes are a promising alternative to alkaline ones, expanding their applications and being actively researched to meet modern energy storage needs. Passivated ZnO layer on the anode. In addition to the problems that still exist in electrolyte and air electrodes, metallic zinc electrodes are also facing the same problems of zinc dendrites, in which deformation and passivation cannot be ignored [3,228]. During the discharge process, when the discharge product Zn(OH)4 2− reaches its maximum solubility, Zn(OH)4 2− decomposes to produce ZnO, which is then deposited on the zinc electrode and blocks the pores of the zinc electrode [229]. The irreversible deposition of ZnO forms a passivation layer that increases the internal resistance of the zinc electrode and affects the anode utilization rate and the rechargeability of the battery [3,230]. Regulation of the concentration of Zn(OH)4 2− and the control of Zn dissolution are the key factors to inhibit ZnO formation. Dendrite formation is a paramount concern in the development of flexible batteries, and it presents immediate challenges for future research endeavors. Addressing this issue is pivotal not only for enhancing the safety and performance of flexible batteries but also for unlocking their full potential in various applications, including wearable electronics, flexible displays, and beyond. Researchers should continue to prioritize dendrite-related research to advance the field and bring us closer to safe and reliable flexible energy storage solutions. Therefore, exploring reasonable and effective methods to inhibit the formation of the ZnO layer is also a critical issue to be solved in the development of rechargeable zinc-air batteries. Effects of ambient conditions. Many Zn-air batteries are conventionally tested in ambient air, where CO2 readily reacts with alkaline electrolytes, resulting in the formation of carbonates. This process has notable consequences for battery performance. Given that the mobility of HCO3 −/CO3 2− ions is lower than that of OH− ions, it ultimately decreases the ionic conductivity. Moreover, the low solubility of carbonates can lead to their deposition on the air electrode, causing blockages in air electrode voids and reducing its active surface area, thereby affecting overall battery performance [5,40,85]. Therefore, the impact of CO2 on ambient air represents a critical scientific inquiry to be addressed. Furthermore, many reported electrochemical performance evaluations of flexible zinc-air batteries have been conducted at a standard room temperature of 25 °C. However, the real-world operating conditions for wearable electronic devices vary seasonally, and the heat generated by electronic components during operation can elevate the temperature. This increase in temperature may have dual effects—it can enhance the solubility of carbonates, delaying their precipitation, but it can also lead to more substantial water loss from the electrolyte, affecting battery performance [13,85] Thus, exploring the temperature effect is another important factor worthy of in-depth investigation. In summary, self-supported air electrodes have made significant progress over the years. Recent advancements have unveiled their substantial potential for future applications, particularly in the realm of portable wearable devices. However, the issues and challenges highlighted in this discussion serve as valuable guidance for researchers, offering opportunities to further enhance the performance of bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts and flexible zinc-air batteries, ultimately propelling them towards greater innovation and eventual commercialization. Chen Xu graduated in 2023 with a master's degree under Prof. Zuofeng Chen at Tongji University. She obtained her bachelor's degree at Tiangong University in 2020. Her research focus on the design and fabrication of bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts and their applications in Zn-air batteries. Jianying Wang is an assistant professor at Tongji University. He obtained his BS degree at Harbin Institute of Technology in 2015 and Ph.D. degree at Tongji University in 2020, followed by working as a postdoctoral fellow at Shanghai Jiao Tong University. His research interests focus on the design and development of efficient electrocatalysts and systems for converting renewable energy and waste carbon resources. Zuofeng Chen got his Ph.D. degree at the University of Hong Kong in 2009 and was a postdoctoral fellow at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and Duke University. He is a full professor at School of Chemical Science and Engineering of Tongji University since 2014. His research interest focuses on new energy materials and the electrocatalysis in energy conversion and storage systems.

coredata.dc:description: Smart wearable devices are regarded to be the next prevailing technology product after smartphones and smart homes, and thus there has recently been rapid development in flexible electronic energy storage devices. Among them, flexible solid-state zinc-air batteries have received widespread attention because of their high energy density, good safety, and stability. Efficient bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts are the primary consideration in the development of flexible solid-state zinc-air batteries, and self-supported air cathodes are strong candidates because of their advantages including simplified fabrication process, reduced interfacial resistance, accelerated electron transfer, and good flexibility. This review outlines the research progress in the design and construction of nanoarray bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts. Starting from the configuration and basic principles of zinc-air batteries and the strategies for the design of bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts, a detailed discussion of self-supported air cathodes on carbon and metal substrates and their uses in flexible zinc-air batteries will follow. Finally, the challenges and opportunities in the development of flexible zinc-air batteries will be discussed.
